titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Lyman Hoover Papers
titlestmt.author: Compiled by Martha Lund Smalley

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday March 26, 2019 at 22:26

did.abstract: The collection relates to the personal and professional life of Lyman Hoover. There is valuable documentation of the work of the YMCA in China from 1930 until the Communist takeover in 1950, including observations of Chinese social and political conditions. Lyman Hoover was a missionary in China under the auspices of the YMCA (1930-1949) and a consultant and representative of the Asia Foundation (formerly known as Committee for a Free Asia) in New York and Taiwan.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Lyman Hoover Papers (RG 9), Special Collections, Yale Divinity School Library.

chronitem.event: Born in Minerva, Ohio, son of Virginia D. and Rev. Guy l. Hoover.
Graduated from Butler University.
Traveling secretary for the Student Volunteer Movement.
Attended Yale Divinity School.
Ordained at the Downey Avenue Christian Church, Indianapolis.
Served as pastor of the Congregational Church in Northford, Ct.
Married Helen L. Kroenke.
Associate regional secretary of Rocky Mountain Field of National Student Division of YMCA's based in Denver.
Appointed to staff of International Committee of YMCA's for service in China.
Studied at the College of Chinese Studies, Peiping.
University Secretary of Peiping YMCA.
Daughter, Carol Virginia, born.
Special lecturer at the College of Chinese Studies, Peiping in the field of Chinese Islam.
Furlough; one semester of study at Yale University. Returned to China without family.
Son, Lyman MacNicholl, born (known as "Mac").
Five month, 5,000 mile tour of war-torn China. Assisted in organization of National Student Relief Committee.
Appointed Associate Executives Student Division, National Committee, YMCA's of China.
Returned to China with family, based in Shanghai.
Associate Executive Secretary, National Student Relief Committee.
Member, Board of Managers, Shanghai American School.
Returned to U.S. with family LH returned to China 1941 Mar.

YMCA headquarters in China transferred from Shanghai to Chungking,Szechuan because of war disturbances. LH worked from that base until 1945 Oct., his work including many long trips among the universities in exile in western China.
Administrative Secretary, National Student Relief Committee.
Furlough in U.S.

Elected Associate General Secretary, National Committee, YMCA's of China. LH had been offered the position of Executive Secretary of American Student YMCA but declined the position in order to continue his work in China.

Returned to China by sailing vessel, visiting YMCA work in South America, Africa, and India. While in China LH was a member of the Business and Educational Committees of United China Relief, the China Nutritional Aid Council and the Chinese American Institute of Cultural Relations.

Returned from Chungking to Shanghai; helped reestablish National YMCA headquarters there. Supervised YMCA work for Japanese and Korean civilian internees and repatriates. Visited various cities and;univer sities in central and northern China, investigating rehabilitation problems. Member, Advisory Council, Chinese National Relief and Rehabilitation Administration.
Furlough in U.S. First year spent largely in traveling and speaking engagements for YMCA.
School year spent in study for M.A. degree at Yale University, including major paper on issues of missionary preparation for overseas work.
Returned to Shanghai with family. Forced to return to U.S. because of health problems of HKH and unsettled conditions in China.
World Services Director for New York City YMCA.
Appointed Trustee of United Board for Christian Higher Education in Asia.
Consultant to Committee for a Free Asia.
Appointed New York Representative of Committee for a Free Asia, which changed its name to the Asia Foundation in 1954.
Visited Taiwan as Representative of Asia Foundation.
Helen K. Hoover died of heart failure.
"Mac" Hoover died of leukemia.
Representative of Asia Foundation in Republic of China (Taiwan).
Married Jane Hunter.
Son, Giles, born.
Retired from Asia Foundation, having served as a consultant for his last ten years of association with the Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lyman Hoover lived and worked in China for sixteen years during the period 1930-1949. His service in various administrative positions under the auspices of the International Committee of the Young Men's Christian Associations involved extensive travel throughout China and close cooperation with Chinese Christian leaders. The documentation of Hoover's work provided by this collection is of particular interest because of the nature of the YMCA's approach to mission work in China. To a greater extent than the missions enterprise of many denominational agencies, the activities of the YMCA in China were characterized by an awareness of and responsiveness to political events and by involvement of Chinese nationals in leadership roles.

While based in Peking, Shanghai or Chungking, Lyman Hoover spent long periods in travel throughout China and he and his YMCA colleagues became well-equipped to provide meaningful analysis of the religious, social, and political conditions that they observed The YMCA correspondence and reports in this collection include interesting comment on the progression of Communist influence in China, with awareness of Communist activities evident as early as 1931. In 1939, for example, Chinese YMCA staff member Kiang Wen Han reported on a trip to Yenan where he visited with university students living in caves and talked with Communist leaders Chou En Lai and Mao Tse Tung. Though Hoover was no longer in China at the height of the Communist takeover, he did continue to receive carbon copies of YMCA correspondence from China which related eyewitness accounts of the "liberation".

Various other topics are well documented by the Hoover Papers. Sino-Japanese relations and the extensive relief and rehabilitation operations carried on with YMCA cooperation during the World War II period are described in correspondence and reports. The study of the Islam religion in China was of particular interest to Hoover from the time that he wrote his B.D. thesis on that subject. The printed material gathered by Hoover during his years in China as well as correspondence with Islamic scholars such as Samuel Zwemer, Isaac Mason, and Claude L. Pickens, Jr. are a valuable resource for information regarding Chinese Muslims. A number of Chinese language pamphlets about Islam which Hoover collected have been placed in the East Asian Collection of the Yale University Library.

Also of interest are the materials in this collection which document Hoover's activities before and after his work in China. The completeness of the collection allows for careful analysis of the factors contributing to Hoover's decision to serve in China, a decision which he held to despite considerable odds. Hoover prepared for missionary service at the Yale Divinity School and the course notes he kept record the substance of lectures by Yale professors such as Kenneth Scott Latourette and Douglas Clyde Macintosh. After his return from China, Hoover completed nearly twenty-five years of work with the Asia Foundation (known as the Committee for a Free Asia prior to 1954). Serving as a consultant and liaison with Asian visitors and diplomats in New York, Hoover came in contact with notables such as U Thant, Dean Rusk, John D. Rockefeller, 3rd, and various Asian ambassadors.

The first series, CORRESPONDENCE, dates from 1902 to 1977 and is divided into Family Correspondence and General Correspondence. Hoover was separated from his family for long periods of time due to the traveling nature of his job, his wife's health and/or political disturbances in China. Letters exchanged between Hoover and his first wife clearly document the strains on family relationships which resulted from the demands of his work. Family correspondence, both within the immediate Hoover family and with the parents and siblings of Lyman and Helen is voluminous and provides a detailed picture of their daily routines and concerns. Early letters exchanged by Hoover's mother and father give insight into the environment in which he was brought up.

Of major importance in the General Correspondence section are the letters related to Hoover's work with the YMCA in China. All YMCA-related correspondence is gathered into one chronologically arranged file which includes letters exchanged with such YMCA notables as Eugene Barnett, Fletcher Brockman, Dalton McClelland, Lennig Sweet, Jay C. Oliver, Paul Moritz, S.C. Leung, Kiang Wen Han, Y.T. Wu and so forth. In conjunction with the printed material in Series II, these letters provide a valuable record of YMCA involvement in China during the period 1930-1950.

Also of interest in the General Correspondence section are Hoover's communications with Yale professors Kenneth S. Latourette and Clarence P. Shedd, his correspondence with the Islamic scholars mentioned above, and scattered contacts with China scholars and religious leaders such as John King Fairbank, Derk Bodde, Walter Judd, John R. Mott, Robert P. Wilder, and Henry P. VanDusen. Hoover exchanged courtesy correspondence with the various U.S. and Asian diplomats with whom he became acquainted through his work at the Asia Foundation. Throughout his career, Hoover corresponded with many Chinese religious leaders and acquaintances.

The second series, NOTES/SUBJECT FILE, consists of holograph notes as well as printed and typescript material dating from 1900 to 1976. These topically arranged materials relate to Hoover's student days, his professional involvements, speaking engagements, his study of Islam in China, a study of missionary preparation for overseas service, etc. One group of sermon :notes dating from 1900-1913 would appear to be those of Hoover's father, Guy Israel Hoover.

The third series, WRITINGS, is the smallest, consisting of twenty-two articles and essays written by Hoover The writings date from 1918 to 1948 and deal primarily with his personal beliefs and relationship to the missions movement, YMCA student work, and Muslims in China.
The fourth series, PERSONAL ITEMS AND MEMORABILIA, contains materials dating from 1907 to 1976 and is divided into six sections:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is arranged as follows:

list.item: 1. Correspondence of the immediate family (1924-1967, n.d.)
2 Correspondence of Helen Kroenke Hoover's family: mother, sisters andbrother-in-law (1928-1967, n.d.)
3. Correspondence of Lyman Hoover's family: parents, siblings, in-laws(1928-1967, n.d.)

B. General Correspondence-arranged alphabetically by author or recipient other than Hoover. Folders labeled with letters such as "A" or "Ba" are followed by individual folders for more notable or frequent correspondents. A large portion of the General Correspondence section is the YMCA-related correspondence file which is arranged chronologically. Personal correspondence with YMCA staff members is located under their names while business-related correspondence is located in the YMCA file.
